meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Schell (Carleton University)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I'm also uh interested in so so we're looking at carbon capture other than DAC. meeting_annotations.speaker: Ellen B. Stechel

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marta Hatzell
meeting_annotations.transcript: So in addition to how to capture it, um, I guess that hand in hand with that goes, should we capture it? meeting_annotations.speaker: Yayuan Liu (Johns Hopkins)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I agree with Marta and also like uh, in addition to methane, what about like nitrous oxide? I mean, both are at similar concentrations, but the lifetime of nitrous oxide was way longer than methane. So I'm I'm curious to hear thoughts on that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marta Hatzell
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess the one thing is why I'm not I know that methane is going up at like a similar trajectory as CO2 and from what I've known about nitrous oxide is, you know, it's been going down largely due to increased um, you know, clean power plants, although with agriculture, it's now I think starting to, you know, had been going down for a long time, but uh, especially ammonia is now rising, which then can contribute to N2O. meeting_annotations.speaker: Yayuan Liu (Johns Hopkins)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm not sure, but I could quickly check. But from what I remembered, that's probably the majority of like anthropogenic contributions from agriculture runoff and uh, from soil, um bacteria, um breaking those uh nitrogen containing compounds down. So, um back in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marta Hatzell
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I know ammonia is is is is growing of an issue and then ammonia can be atmos in the atmosphere converted to um, but yeah, I agree with you. That's an interesting thing. We we hear methane, but we don't hear NOx as much. Um, yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I think that the challenge of capturing methane because of the nature of the molecule itself, its chemical properties, the fact that it's orders of magnitude lower than CO2, um and the lifetime issues that Marta raised all identify it as a extremely significant challenge and therefore, you know, maybe maybe one not worth going after. Um, at least I'm not choosing to go after it. I'm really interested in methane conversion. Um, I think there's a lot of things that can be done in a really productive way for methane conversion, but um, I think that, you know, PPB methane capture is maybe a bit of a wild goose chase.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Schell (Carleton University)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I was wondering if maybe Peter has uh some experience as a geoscientist in permafrost. So when the concentrations when the permafrost melts and the concentrations become higher, what do we do?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I'll cycle back to the stability to try to uh uh switch us to another topic because Will talked about that in the very beginning. I wanted to hear if anybody else had any stability comments. And I think the stability issue is one that is very technology dependent. Um, so, you know, um just under ambient temperate conditions, if you think about the major ways that people have already published taking CO2 out of the atmosphere, you know, you have stabilities on the order of, you know, probably weeks to decades for the technology and the materials and um then you have to look at sort of the life cycle techno economic analysis aspect of it and and find out how long is long enough and that's going to vary by technology as well.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ellen B. Stechel
